bibl.title: Letter from S.J. Quinn to Philip Showalter Hench, November 24, 1952

div1.p: Quinn instructs Hench on the best way to ship boards and lumber salvaged from the remains of Building No. 1 from Cuba to the United States.

div1.head: Letter from S.J. Quinn to Philip Showalter Hench, November 24, 1952
div1.p:
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
BUREAU OF CUSTOMS
St. Paul 1, Minnesota
November 24, 1952 OFFICE OF THE DEPUTY COLLECTOR
Dr. Philip S. Hench
c/o Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Sir:

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter of November 22nd, with fur-
ther reference to the contemplated importation by you of boards and lumber sal-
vaged from the remains of “Reed's Building No. 1.”

Upon a rereading of my letter of November 14th I find I neglected
to suggest you endeavor to have the shipment move by parcel post, even if it
necessitates sending it in several parcels, as such shipments valued at not in
excess of $100., per shipment (not per package) are handled on an informal basis,
i.e., by correspondence rather than by the personal appearance of the importer,
or his broker, at the Customs office at the port of first arrival, and while the
costs of mailing may be considerably larger than the costs of shipping by freight
or express the other costs, such as Customs Brokers fees, etc., in getting a
freight or express shipment cleared through Customs will usually run the total
outlay considerably higher than the total costs of mailing the same shipment.

If the articles are shipped by parcel post and a statement addressed
to the U. S. Customs officer explaining the nature and purpose of the shipment is
enclosed in each parcel, I believe you will experience no difficulty in having
the boards or lumber cleared through Customs, provided, of course, the wood has
been examined and fumigated prior to shipment, if necessary, and that a statement
to that effect is also enclosed with each mail parcel.

We can furnish you with the names and addresses of hundreds of licens-
ed customhouse brokers in New York if you wish, but since there is no assurance
the shipment or shipments will move through New York we will await your request
for the furnishing of brokers' names and addresses.

Respectfully,
S. J. QUINN
Deputy Collector in Charge
SJQ:cg

December 1, 1952
Mr. S. J. Quinn
Deputy Collector in Charge
Treasury Department
Bureau of Customs
St. Paul 1, Minnesota
Dear Mr. Quinn:

Your letter arrived just as Doctor Hench was
leaving for Cuba. He was very grateful for
it and will acknowledge it in person on his
return.

Sincerely yours,
Secretary to
P. S. Hench, M.D.
ALC
